title: Ticket #7887: Questions about condor 8.9.8 and Token Authentication
description:
On a test cluster at LIGO Hanford Observatory with a condor host, submit host, and a node (xcondor, xpcdev1, and xnode1 respectively) we are running condor 8.9.8 and I am testing Token Authentication.

While I can get it to work, I'm having trouble setting up Authentication/Authorization to allow a user to submit from the submit host without a token.

My hope is to allow a user logged onto xpcdev1 to use FS Authentication to run condor_submit.

I also run into a few other questions while trying to set this up.

1. Here's what I've done:

i. Based on the SEC settings for Token Authentication given here,

https://htcondor.readthedocs.io/en/latest/admin-manual/security.html#token-authentication

and the example ALLOW settings for user-based Authorization given here,

https://htcondor.readthedocs.io/en/latest/admin-manual/security.html#example-of-authorization-security-configuration

and the condor_token_request_auto_approve command given here,

https://htcondor.readthedocs.io/en/latest/admin-manual/security.html#quick-configuration-of-security

on the test cluster, xcondor, xpcdev1, and xnode1 at LIGO Hanford, I installed this config file: 

[root@xcondor ~]# cat /etc/condor/config.d/50-test-security
SEC_NEGOTIATOR_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS
SEC_COLLECTOR_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS
SEC_DAEMON_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS
SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS= IDTOKENS
SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS
ALLOW_READ            = *@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/*
ALLOW_WRITE           = *@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/*.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu
ALLOW_ADMINISTRATOR   = condor@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu
ALLOW_CONFIG          = condor@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu
ALLOW_NEGOTIATOR      = condor@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu
ALLOW_DAEMON          = condor@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu/*.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu
#ALL_DEBUG = D_CAT D_ALL:2 D_SECURITY
ALL_DEBUG = D_SECURITY

ii. However, probably not surprisingly, this failed on xcondor:

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 10.21.199.0/24 -lifetime 3600

iii. If I create a token:

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_create -identity root@dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu

and install it in,

~/.condor/tokens.d/token

then it still fails,

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 10.21.199.0/24 -lifetime 3600

Failed to create new auto-approval rule: SECMAN:2010:Received "DENIED" from server for user condor_pool@ using method IDTOKENS.

iv. However, in /etc/condor/config.d/50-test-security, if I change,

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS

to

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = FS, IDTOKENS

then it works,

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 10.21.199.0/24 -lifetime 3600

Successfully installed auto-approval rule for netblock 10.21.199.0/24 with lifetime of 1.00 hours Remote daemon reports no un-approved requests pending.

Cool!

I wanted to use FS to Authenticate in any case, when running condor admin commands as root on a host.

v. But on xpcdev1 as root, if I change,

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS

to

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = FS, IDTOKENS

and become user gregory.mendell, then these fail:

-bash-4.2$ condor_q -debug

10/13/20 16:33:26 Can't open directory "/etc/condor/passwords.d" as PRIV_UNKNOWN, errno: 13 (Permission denied) 10/13/20 16:33:26 SECMAN: required authentication with schedd at <10.21.199.11:9618> failed, so aborting command QUERY_JOB_ADS_WITH_AUTH.

-- Failed to fetch ads from: <10.21.199.11:9618?addrs=10.21.199.11-9618&alias=xpcdev1.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu&noUDP&sock=schedd_576483_f778> : xpcdev1.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method -bash-4.2$ cd public_html/testosg/localtest/ -bash-4.2$ condor_submit localhelloworld.sub Submitting job(s) ERROR: Failed to connect to local queue manager AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method

However, if I create a token for myself,

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_create -identity gregory.mendell@xcondor

and install it in ~/.condor/tokens.d/token under my home directory on xpcdev1 then condor_q and condor_submit work!

That's nice.

But here's my question:

How can I get condor_q and condor_submit to work for myself (or any user) who in on the submit host (xpcdev1 for this test) without having to issue a token for user?

2. After trying the above I also changed,

SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS= IDTOKENS

to

SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS= FS, IDTOKENS

This seemed to allow condor submit as user gregory.mendell on xpcdev1 to work without a token.

But two things still didn't work:

i. Without a token, condor_status fails:

-bash-4.2$ condor_status

Error: communication error AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method AUTHENTICATE:1004:Failed to authenticate using FS

This probably makes sense, since authentication with the Collector on xcondor will fail without a token.

ii. While condor_submit did work without a token, using FS authentication, the job never ran.

So far I have been unsuccessful in finding authentication setting that allow user gregory.mendell on xpcdev1 submit jobs and have them run, without a token.

3. A couple of other things I've noticed,

i. When condor was installed it created this file,

[root@xcondor ~]# ls -l /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

-rw------- 1 root root 64 Sep 30 10:06 /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

It belongs to root, and when things fail, as above, one sees:

Can't open directory "/etc/condor/passwords.d" as PRIV_UNKNOWN, errno: 13 (Permission denied)

ii. Also, I had to copy /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL from xcondor to xpcdev1 and xnode1 to get things to work.

iii. Finally, this directory, which belongs to condor,

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# ls -ld /etc/condor/tokens.d/

drwx------ 2 condor condor 6 Jul 30 17:01 /etc/condor/tokens.d/

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# ls -l /etc/condor/tokens.d/

total 0

is always empty.

I'm not sure if i-iii above are expected or not. I thought tokens would show up in /etc/condor/tokens.d/ for daemon to daemon authentication. But maybe I misunderstood the documentation.

Thanks for your help!
remarks:
2020-Nov-17 10:20:29 by gmendell:
One other issue: When token authentication works, it works with a token that is world readable:

-bash-4.2$ ls -al /home/gregory.mendell/.condor/tokens.d/token

-rw-rw-r-- 1 gregory.mendell gregory.mendell 280 Sep 28 10:11 /home/gregory.mendell/.condor/tokens.d/token

2020-Nov-24 15:47:33 by gmendell:
Notes from 24 Nov. 2020 between Greg Mendell and Zach Miller.

1. On the topic of allowing users to run condor_submit from the submit host without the user having a token, to clarify the above, add FS to BOTH of these options works:

SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS= FS, IDTOKENS

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = FS, IDTOKENS

With the above, user gregory.mendell can successfully submit jobs without a token on xpcdev1, which runs the schedd.

2. However, user gregory.mendell cannot run condor_status without a token:

-bash-4.2$ whoami

gregory.mendell

-bash-4.2$ uname -a

Linux xpcdev1 3.10.0-1160.6.1.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Nov 17 13:59:11 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

-bash-4.2$ condor_status

Error: communication error

AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method

AUTHENTICATE:1004:Failed to authenticate using FS

3. On the central manager, xcondor, adding these options,

SEC_READ_AUTHENTICATION = OPTIONAL

ALLOW_READ = *.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu

did not fix the problem of running condor_status.

Trying ALLOW_READ = * didn't work either.

4. There is a mystery around condor_status and user root on the submit host running the schedd. Note that user root does not have a token. (Early on, as indicated in this ticket above, I created a token for root, but removed it early on too.)

i. When FS is included in the options above, condor_status run as root fails:

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# condor_status

Error: communication error

AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method

AUTHENTICATE:1004:Failed to authenticate using IDTOKENS

AUTHENTICATE:1004:Failed to authenticate using FS

ii. When FS is NOT included in the options above, i.e., setting,

SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS= IDTOKENS

SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = IDTOKENS

and running condor_status as root, it succeeds, even though root does not have a token:

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# condor_status

Name OpSys Arch State Activity LoadAv Mem ActvtyTime

slot1@xnode1.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu LINUX X86_64 Unclaimed Idle 0.000 1837 0+18:54:51 

               Machines Owner Claimed Unclaimed Matched Preempting  Drain


  X86_64/LINUX        1     0       0         1       0          0      0


         Total        1     0       0         1       0          0      0

though it still fails when run as user gregory.mendell,

-bash-4.2$ whoami

gregory.mendell

-bash-4.2$ condor_status

Error: communication error

SECMAN:2002:Configuration Problem: The security policy is invalid.

5. Another mystery is what actually happened when running condor_token_request_auto_approve succeeded:

[root@xcondor ~]# condor_token_request_auto_approve -netblock 10.21.199.0/24 -lifetime 3600

Before the above succeeded, on the submit box, xpcdev1, running the schedd, the logs showed this failure,

0/23/20 13:28:36 (pid:704572) Failed to request a new token: DAEMON:1:Failed to recieve response from remote daemon at at '<10.21.199.1:9618?alias=xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu>'

After condor_token_request_auto_approve succeeded on the central manager, xcondor, then the logs on the submit box, xpcdev1, showed,

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) SECMAN: resuming command 1 UPDATE_SCHEDD_AD to collector xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu from TCP port 1208 (non-blocking).

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) Inserting pre-auth metadata for TOKEN.

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) SECMAN: resuming command 1 UPDATE_SCHEDD_AD to collector xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu from TCP port 1208 (non-blocking).

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) SECMAN: new session, doing initial authentication.

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) SECMAN: Auth methods: TOKEN

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) AUTHENTICATE: setting timeout for <10.21.199.1:9618?alias=xcondor.dcs.ligo-wa.caltech.edu> to 20.

10/23/20 13:33:29 (pid:704990) HANDSHAKE: in handshake(my_methods = 'TOKEN')

and job submission worked!

However, nothing appears in /etc/condor/tokens.d:

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# ls -al /etc/condor/tokens.d

total 0

drwx------ 2 condor condor 6 Nov 20 07:18 .

drwxr-xr-x 7 root root 215 Nov 23 16:22 ..

even though SEC_TOKEN_SYSTEM_DIRECTORY is set to:

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# condor_config_val SEC_TOKEN_SYSTEM_DIRECTORY

/etc/condor/tokens.d

Note that the password file does exist:

[root@xpcdev1 ~]# ls -al /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

-rw------- 1 root root 64 Sep 30 10:06 /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

which I assume must be used somehow.

6. Finally, on the call I repeated that when user gregory.mendell has a token, everything works (condor_submit and condor_status), but it works even though the token is world readable:

-bash-4.2$ whoami

gregory.mendell

-bash-4.2$ uname -a

Linux xpcdev1 3.10.0-1160.6.1.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Nov 17 13:59:11 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

-bash-4.2$ ls -al ~/.condor/tokens.d/token

-rw-rw-r-- 1 gregory.mendell gregory.mendell 280 Sep 28 10:11 /home/gregory.mendell/.condor/tokens.d/token

7. LIGO hopes to switch to Token Authentication when HTCondor has a release that the condor team believes works within their expectations/documentation, and once LIGO is able to test it successfully so that users logged onto a submit host running the schedd can run condor_q, condor_submit and condor_status without a token, with FS authentication on the submit host, and setting on the central manager collector host to allow condor_status to work.

2020-Nov-24 15:58:56 by zmiller:
Greg, two things I should have also included:
  1. On any machine that's going to query the collector (for example, the submit machine where you were running condor_status) you should include this in the config: 
    SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION = OPTIONAL
  2. Make sure you run condor_reconfig on both the submit machine and central manager if you didn't already.

I forgot that if the client is configured to require authentication, then it will insist on doing so even if the server says it is optional. The config setting in #1 should fix that.
